posts.cooked:
Here is the cleaned-up version:

I am an incoming junior interested in CAD and need a good laptop for it. Currently, I’m using Inventor on my grandma’s old laptop, which is outdated and too slow for my needs. I have a budget of around $800 and would like to find a laptop that will last me through college. The team uses Inventor, and having a portable device would be helpful for my studies, mainly for CAD tasks and basic school work like Google Docs. There were some good recommendations in a recent thread, but since I’m new to choosing laptops, I’m seeking more specific advice. Thank you!

posts.name: Titus Casas
posts.cooked: A decent GPU is essential for graphics and rendering tasks, along with a powerful CPU suitable for CAD, simulations, and calculations. While a touchscreen isn't strictly necessary for CAD, having a reliable mouse is important. Opting for an Intel i7 or i9 processor, or their AMD equivalents, is ideal. Additionally, selecting any recent GPU is advisable, provided it does not include integrated graphics. Brands like Acer deliver excellent laptops, with Dell and Lenovo also performing well; however, Acer tends to offer the best value within its price range.

posts.name: Zakk Jackson
posts.cooked: So like I said in that thread my friend just picked up one of these and it is really nice and would work well for CAD. And it is well within your budget.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked: An important criterion often overlooked in laptop specifications is thermal power. While boosting the CPU to 4.4 GHz is impressive, tools like Fusion may achieve this occasionally, yet inadequate cooling prevents sustained performance at such speeds. The Victus design lacks evident airflow features, suggesting it may operate under thermal constraints most of the time. Regrettably, laptops prioritizing this aspect are prohibitively expensive, especially premium gaming models.

posts.name: Titus Casas
posts.cooked: If you want to compare COUs or GPUs I recommend this site. Our computer hardware comparisons assist you in making purchasing decisions.

posts.name: SLAB-Mr.Thomas
posts.cooked: I’ve had good luck with used equipment from backmarket. Here’s an example of what you can get for $800. Every day has a wide variety of computers of different ages.

link_counts.title: Refurbished tech that's better for the planet | Back Market

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: I would look to the used market for CAD software and accessories. "Interested in CAD" refers to developing skills, while "trying to become a professional" implies aiming for career success. My perspective is that you should prioritize portability, reasonable power, and screen quality in your devices. For college students, eventually, you'll access more powerful laptops, so during studies, focus on balance. If your laptop is meant for daily use, aim for a good mix of portability, power, and thermals. Additionally, invest in a decent mouse, enhancing its features can improve efficiency within your budget. When transitioning to cloud-based tools like Onshape, consider their integration into your workflow, which might alter your hardware strategy.

posts.name: Mike Schreiber
posts.cooked:
CAD performance is often limited by single-core CPU efficiency, so investing in more cores may not yield significant improvements. A 6-core CPU is likely sufficient, while an 8-core might offer a reasonable upgrade, though it doesn’t necessarily boost CAD capabilities. Comparing CPUs across generations requires focusing on single-core benchmarks rather than overall performance metrics.

For adequate CAD operations, a decent GPU is essential, especially for handling larger models. However, even entry-level dedicated laptops from the past five years can manage CAD tasks effectively, making high-end integrated graphics adapters unnecessary.

It’s important to allocate at least 32 GB of RAM. While 16 GB is insufficient, the additional memory needed is relatively small, and finding reasonably priced laptops with more RAM becomes increasingly difficult.

Storage size is a personal choice, but I recommend at least 512 GB for effective CAD work.

If you’re planning to use a laptop for CAD, a 15-16-inch model is ideal due to its screen real estate. If space is a concern, consider a smaller laptop paired with an external or second monitor.

posts.name: Isaac Proctor
posts.cooked: Get a base model M4 MacBook Air. It offers excellent battery life and a great touchpad experience, though note that a mouse is available as an alternative. While macOS natively doesn't support In inventor, you can use Boot Camp, Onshape, or Fusion—each has its own considerations. If you require more than 256GB of storage, consider purchasing an external SSD to avoid being charged excessively by Apple for additional space.

posts.name: joel truher
posts.cooked:
I spend a lot of time working with Fusion 360 on an 11th Gen Intel Core i7 machine with integrated Intel Iris XE graphics. The setup runs smoothly on a 14-inch screen with 16GB RAM. While occasional performance issues arise with complex assemblies, these instances are rare. Carrying the device around is convenient, though I occasionally wish for a slightly larger screen for better workspace flexibility.

Using a single machine for all tasks, including the Driver Station, is very convenient. I'm unsure if Windows-only restrictions will apply by 2027, but they definitely exist in 2026.

posts.name: Sam
posts.cooked: A powerful laptop is overrated. Battery life, chassis quality, screen quality, and weight are the only metrics that matter to me now. Anything that doesn’t thermally throttle isn’t truly portable. I’ve had 17-inch workstations. I’d rather have an ultrabook and use hardware remotely as needed. I often leave my iPad at home and bring only my MBA 13 on trips.

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
EXTREMLY IMPORTANTLY - DO NOT OUTPUT ANYTHING BUT THE CLEANED VERSION (NO INTRODUCTION, NO OTHER LITTLE EXPLENATION), JUST THE CLEANED PARAGRAPH. 

Having a 17-inch laptop with a 4k screen for CAD offers extra real estate, enhancing your workspace efficiency. Consider exploring [slickdeals.net](https://slickdeals.net) to find deals within your budget, featuring refurbished and open-box options tailored to meet your requirements.

posts.name: Harry C
posts.cooked: At about midway through my undergrad, I got a ThinkPad T14s from an online auction. What I discovered from that experience was that A) ThinkPad laptops are fantastic, and B) Refurbished or Secondhand options are usually the best deal. I tend to get absorbed in the details—specifically, the graphics processing unit (GPU) and central processing unit (CPU)—but my reality is that you don't need a top-of-the-line GPU or CPU. My ThinkPad remains my daily driver, and I'm thoroughly happy with it. If I were in your situation again, I'd prioritize additional RAM, maybe some extra battery life. Inventor is still my favorite CAD software, and I can handle it just fine. We maintain a volunteer laptop list with a few notes if you're interested.

posts.name: Skye Leake
posts.cooked: The text is extremely important here. Additionally, the second-hand market offers numerous advantages, such as access to reviews and real-world experiences, helping users understand product strengths and weaknesses better.

posts.name: Titus Casas
posts.cooked: In the end, it comes down to your purpose, since basic documentation and CAD don’t demand much, but if you want to play with it or perform detailed CAD tasks, you’ll need high-end specs like a good CPU and GPU.

posts.name: Ian Osborn
posts.cooked: HP laptops are highly reliable and recommended for use, particularly in professional settings such as blue chip medical device companies. My current and previous workplaces have chosen HP products, including the HP Z Books, primarily due to their performance and durability. Standard engineering laptops equipped with dedicated graphics cards, like the HP Z Book, often come with significant discounts compared to manufacturers' suggested retail prices. My personal laptop, an HP Z Book with a P1000 card, has served well for CAD tasks, and my work laptops, also HP Z Books featuring A2000 cards, have proven robust and reliable. These laptops consistently feature aluminum casings and have demonstrated exceptional longevity.

posts.name: David Kravets
posts.cooked:
Here’s my personal recommendation for our teams’ software/cam/3DP/drive laptops—a mentor model from Onshape. I prefer purchasing a new one since it guarantees both the laptop and battery are in top condition, though it does come with a higher cost. 

The ASUS Vivobook S 16 2.8K OLED AI Laptop, powered by the Intel Core Ultra 9 285H, boasts 16GB RAM, 1TB SSD, and a backlit keyboard, running Windows 11 Home. Its standout features include an excellent screen quality, impressive battery life, and exceptional portability—all attributes prioritize over raw performance.

However, lacking a dedicated graphics processor could limit performance for graphics-intensive tasks. For users needing more graphical power, consider beefier alternatives, which often trade off battery life, cost, and portability. Be aware that 16GB of RAM may feel insufficient if you open multiple Chrome tabs simultaneously.

An alternative option is the ASUS Vivobook 16 F1605VA-MH96, available at Micro Center, which offers 32GB RAM and an Indie Black finish. While its screen quality is slightly inferior, it’s worth considering if you value additional RAM significantly.

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: An old ThinkPad on Craigslist will be great; it should be super cheap.

Adding recommendations for a secondhand laptop, many manufacturers such as Dell and HP offer "business-class" laptops like Latitude and EliteBook, which are more expensive than consumer models but have better build quality and are easier to repair. Businesses often purchase these laptops in large quantities and replace them after a few years as they stay updated. Used laptops from brands like Dell and HP can typically be found for a fraction of their original price on platforms like eBay or through specialized websites. For example, all of Team 3494's laptops are used Dell Latitudes procured from our local university's surplus store, while my personal laptop is an HP EliteBook obtained from eBay.

posts.name: Matthew L
posts.cooked: Macs are somewhat expensive and can be challenging to repair or upgrade. Additionally, I believe that 256GB is insufficient for most computers since it tends to fill up quickly, and external drives should primarily serve as backup solutions. For professional use, such as CAD, I recently acquired an upgradeable AMD ThinkPad and decided to move on from it.
